It was a historic day for Hillsborough County Public Schools.

This morning, Superintendent Addison Davis and Principal David Brown along with district leaders held a press conference with media to officially open Sumner High School, our first new high school built in more than ten years.

Sumner High School is the largest high school our district has ever constructed at 265,000 square feet.

It is located at 10650 County Road 672 in Riverview, in the fast-growing area of southeastern Hillsborough County. This state-of-the-art, picturesque campus will welcome 9th-11th grade students this first year, adding a senior class the next school year.

Sumner High School will also be home to an innovative, one-of-a-kind program in our district called Academy 2027.

This morning, Superintendent Davis announced each school in our district will receive upgraded MERV-13 air filters, which improves ventilation and can help mitigate COVID-19 risks.

The CDC and the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE) has recommended school districts across the nation install these upgraded filters as students return back to the classroom.

In addition, engineers will assess indoor air quality, ventilation, temperature, humidity, mechanical systems and domestic water following CDC, ASHRAE and OSHA guidance to help mitigate the spread of viruses and bacteria. Engineers also conducted an assessment of indoor air quality along with CO2 sensor accuracy and exhaust fan operations.

We are taking all precautions to reopen in the safest manner possible.

More than half of our schools will be converted to MERV 13 filters by August 24th, with full installation set for completion by October 1.

Students in Liisa DiTarando's Social and Emotional Learning Class at McKitrick Elementary were devastated when they couldn't perform songs from the popular Broadway play "Hamilton" at the end of the school year due to COVID.

Mrs. DiTarando used the play as a teaching tool for her students, some who are on the Autism spectrum.

Determined not to give up, one of her students suggested a Zoom performance instead. To make it happen, the class got help from an L.A. filmmaker, along with actors and actresses to make their performance shine on video. Now, it's getting a lot of well-deserved attention online, and was even retweeted by the actor who plays George Washington in Hamilton!

"There are a lot of wonderful Social and Emotional learning lessons built into the play. We explored concepts such as empathy, perspective taking, kindness, friendship, loyalty and communication, all while learning some great songs," said Liisa DiTarando.

She believes this musical gave her students a voice ‚Äì and now they‚Äôre thrilled their rendition is getting rave reviews!

Mrs. DiTarando used the play as a teaching tool for her students, some who are on the Autism spectrum.

Determined not to give up, one of her students suggested a Zoom performance instead. To make it happen, the class got help from an L.A. filmmaker, along with actors and actresses to make their performance shine on video. Now, it's getting a lot of well-deserved attention online, and was even retweeted by the actor who plays George Washington in Hamilton!

"There are a lot of wonderful Social and Emotional learning lessons built into the play. We explored concepts such as empathy, perspective taking, kindness, friendship, loyalty and communication, all while learning some great songs," said Liisa DiTarando.

She believes this musical gave her students a voice ‚Äì and now they‚Äôre thrilled their rendition is getting rave reviews!

Hillsborough County Public Schools will hold graduations for the Class of 2020 virtually, following a sharp spike in COVID-19 cases in our community. Over the last few months, district administrators have worked tirelessly on an in-person graduation plan with increased sanitation measures, social distancing and required masks. However, with the current status of coronavirus cases in Hillsborough County, district leaders have made a decision that we believe is in the best interest of our graduates and their families.

Our district is contracting with an outside vendor to create virtual graduation videos that will be shared with our families. Each high school will also celebrate their graduates with drive-thru diploma ceremonies where seniors can don their cap and gown and take the traditional graduation photo with their principal, of course socially distanced.

We hope our entire community will celebrate our Seniors and wish them well as they embark on the next chapter in their lives. Please share your well wishes on social media platforms and include the hashtag #HCPSGrads2020

If ignored, mental health problems can interfere with children‚Äôs learning, developments, relationships, and physical health. Our objective is to increase mental health awareness, improve climate & culture of schools, adhere to protocols for threat assessments, develop policies that enhance the whole child, decrease mental health stigma, and decrease
violent, aggressive & disruptive behavior.

The ‚ÄúNot I, But We‚Äù Teen Advocacy Group for #MentalHealthAwareness was formed in 2018 by Valerie Muzyka, current Junior at Sickles High School. The groups‚Äô purpose is to replace the ‚ÄúI‚Äù in mental illness with the ‚ÄúWE‚Äù in mental wellness in order to make strides towards eradicating the stigma that surrounds the mental health community. Their mission is to cultivate a welcoming community of students who work together to establish a safe environment in which fellow peers are comfortable listening to the important discussion of mental health and learn how they can help themselves as well as each other.

In 2019, Valerie began to work alongside our Student Services team to develop her group and launch it district-wide at the SAVE Club Showcase in March of this year. We are so excited to see what Valerie has in store for this group in the future! #MentalHealthMatters

The Collaborative for Academic, Social, and Emotional Learning (CASEL) defined SEL more than twenty years ago to help make evidence-based social and emotional learning (SEL) an integral part of education from preschool through high school. This month, we are digging deeper into each competency of Social Emotional Learning that can be taught in many ways from the framework by CASEL.

This week, we will focus on Self‚ÄìAwareness. It is defined by the ability to accurately recognize one‚Äôs own emotions, thoughts, and values and how they influence behavior. Parents and guardians can help children develop self-awareness by being honest about their own emotions. Educators can help by teaching the vocabulary of emotions, modeling behavior, and supporting students as they grow in self-awareness.

SEL eLearning Tip of the Day: Give yourself permission to take a break when you are starting to feel overwhelmed. Write down how you feel and try to identify your emotions.

#SELTips #SELHCPS or #SELGoals

Congratulations on a great Set Up for Success Week!
Here are today's most pressing questions, answered:

Q: You just expanded your Grab-and-Go sites beginning Monday. Am I allowed to go to the closest school, or do I have to pick up meals from where my child is enrolled?

A: Your student can pick up meals from any of our 147 sites, regardless of where they are enrolled.

Q: Does my child have to be on free and reduced lunch in order to take advantage of the Grab-and-Go sites?

A: Any student under the age of 18 can take advantage of the free meals at our 147 Grab-and-Go sites. We are also accommodating students with special needs under the age of 21.

Q: My child was supposed to register for kindergarten, but school is closed. What do I do?

A: Contact your school's administration next week for plans on how your school will be handling kindergarten registration during the closure.

For a list of FAQs, please visit: HillsboroughSchools.org/coronavirus

This young man is a student at Lomax Elementary Magnet in east Tampa... And he is AMAZING!

His name is Landric and in 2018 he received $100 from his great-grandmother to buy whatever he wanted for Christmas.

Instead, Landric used that $100 to start his own charity where he would read books to preschoolers and give them their own copy of the book!

His dream has become a reality. He started Landric's Read and Share... And on January 22, he read and shared books with 240 preschoolers!

Landric also received a Dr. MLK Jr. Day of Service grant for $5000 to buy more books.
